lines.text: You married?
No, I play the harmonica.
What we want is more humane killers!
And I'm not a thief, really. I've never found anything worth keeping.

Never underrate the wily Pathan. What we're going on to now is the wily Pathan, followed the use of and handling of anti-gas carpet. The Pathan lives in India. India is a hot, strange country. It's full of wily Pathans and they're up to wily things, which is why I always wear spurs, even in cold weather. Now, my advice to you is always to keep your rifle strapped to a suitable portion of your body - your leg is good. Otherwise, you'll find the wily Pathan will strip himself mother-naked, grease himself all over - slippery as an eel - make off with your rifle, which is a crime. Any questions so far, or can we take gas?
Sir, has the pathan gone over to Hitler, sir?
Grammar school boy?
Sir.
No, he has not. Too wily for that, the wily Pathan, you'll find.
Then shall we be fighting him in this war, sir?
Of course we will, boy! The British Army has always fought the wily Pathan. Stripped mother-naked, under the tent brailings like a snake, he is.
Why?

[increasingly annoyed]
Why, what? Why, what? We want to get on to gas. May save your life one day, gas.
Er, why has the British Army always fought the wily Pathan, sir?

[very incensed]
Because he's just like you are, a damn wily troublemaker! What's your name in full? How did you get into an O.C.T.U. without knowing your history?
[sigh]
God help your men. They'll be torn apart by the wily Pathan.
That's the way to beat the Hun - dig in, then break through with sword and lance.
[slight pause]
I think.

[talking aloud to himself]
I can't, I fear, I can't march properly on my own, as an officer, in the public eye.

[sitting in back of a truck, smoking, holding a broom]
Isn't that sickening when that happens to a chap? Couldn't your drill instructor do something about it? Like a quick jab up the crotch with a broom bass?
[holds up broom]

[standing atop a desert fortification]
Fourth Muskets, aren't you?

[on the ground]
Sir.
Been expecting you. I'm your link to Army. Blue, white, and two reds.
I'm green, green, green, sir.
Oh ho ho ho, I know you are.

Well, our officer calls me up and he says to me, he says, "Musketeer Gripweed..." He was a tall chap, some would call him weedy. I did. He said to me, and bear in mind that we were some few hundred miles behind enemy lines. He said, "green, green, green," so I did.

[enters scene dressed as a clown, pulling a hobby horse, as if acting a scene]
Will you take my horse, sir?

[to Goodbody]
Take no large notice, sir. He is working what is known as ticket, sir. Keeps the lads amused.
[Clapper, Drouge, and Spool join Juniper, dressed normally]
Pick those bits up, Gripweed!
[joining the scene]
Where's your tin hat gone, Juniper?
Losing by neglect, sir!
If I catch you without your tin hat in a battle zone again, I'll ram it down your throat!
Losing by neglect, one mess tin.
One mess tin!
Did you have your name on it?
[aside, to Goodbody]
Take no notice, sir.
Scratched on!
Pull these...
Scratched on?
...men together!
Scored it!
How dare you disfigure government property? Six days royal warrant. March him off, Musket Major. Two men!
[exeunt Juniper, Clapper, Drogue, and Spool]

[to Goodbody]
Ought to camouflage up, sir, or go - or go get the scrim up, sir, if you're stopping. Us in our, uh, vests here, sir. Exposed to all manner of nasty -

[interrupting, angry but calm]
I'm going to explode, but I won't. I think the roller, don't you?
[walks to background]

[re-enters scene still dressed as a clown, Drogue, Spool, Gripweed, and Clapper in tow]
Bayonet!
Bayonet?
Where's your bayonet?
Must have left it sticking in the enemy, sir!
Spur!
Where?
Where's your spur?
Must have left it sticking in the horse, sir!

[calls out]
Two men!
[exeunt players]

[walks back to Transom and ex-Dooley, points his finger at ex-Dooley, shouting]
There! On the end of my finger!

[re-enter players]
Finger!
Finger?
Musketeer Juniper, where's your finger?
Must have left it sticking up the Khyber Pass, sir!
Self-inflicted injury! March him off, Musket Major! Two - wait for it!
[pause, players posed as if frozen while running]
Two men!
[exeunt players]
Mind you, I'm working class.
Oh. I had a grandfather who was working class. Until he sold it.

I fought for three reasons. I can't remember what they were. The first reason gets you in, and the reason when you are in is staying alive. I won't know the reason they find afterwards, but it will be a very good one for why it was fought. I'm sure I'll be glad.
